description:
A doctor-led breakdown of why reta reduced tumor volume in preclinical cancer models.

This wasn’t about killing cancer cells.
It was about changing the biology cancer depends on.

Reta improved insulin sensitivity and glucose control
Reduced obesity-driven hormonal signaling
Shifted the tumor immune environment toward anti-tumor activity
Limited the metabolic pathways tumors use to grow

When metabolic health improves and immune suppression drops, tumor progression slows. That’s the mechanism discussed here.

Human studies are still yet to be done. 

Educational discussion only. Not medical advice. Always consult a qualified healthcare professional before starting or stopping any medication or peptide.

#cancer #wellness #weightloss #peptides #medical
transcript: Retitrutide has mostly been talked about for weight loss, but there's a study that came out this year that talks about how it affects cancer progression. This paper is from March of 2025, and it hasn't gone viral, but I wanna see what the researchers were trying to understand here. The effects of retitrutide on metabolic changes related to tumor progression and development, specifically in pancreatic and lung adenocarcinoma. And so that makes a lot of sense because we already know obesity leads to many other diseases, but what do they find in this study? Retitrutide decreased tumor engraftment, delayed tumor onset, and reduced tumor growth over time. So fewer tumors found, they showed up later, and they grew much slower. So was this just a mechanism of weight loss, or did the study account for other things there? In this study, they also compared it to semiglutide as a separate group, but what they did do was they had calorie-restricted and weight-matched groups, and retitrutide showed far better tumor suppression than the other groups. Retitrutide did so through increasing antigen-presenting cells, decreasing immunosuppressive cells, and increasing pro-inflammatory pathways related to tumor progression. So then what happened after they stopped the drug in some models? Even after stopping retitrutide, we saw in the control groups that tumor progression was slower. All right, so this is some pretty cool data. Now, how should we interpret this result, and what does this mean for cancer? This doesn't mean that retitrutide is a cancer treatment like chemotherapy. It only means that mediating the metabolic health and immune function can positively affect cancer outcomes. Now, retitrutide still needs to be tested for human cancer progression. However, this is a good starting point, and this is how science should be talked about. Cool, calm, and collected. Just interpreting data.

▪️What is a Peptide?

A peptide is a short chain of amino acids linked together by peptide bonds. Think of peptides as smaller versions of proteins, typically containing 2 to 50 amino acids.

▪️Why Are Peptides Important?

Peptides play vital roles in our bodies, including:

Hormone Regulation: For example, insulin is a peptide hormone that helps control blood sugar levels.
Immune Response: Peptides can help our immune system fight off infections.
Cell Signaling: They act as messengers, helping cells communicate with each other.

transcript: Big Pharma doesn't want you to know that there's a peptide stack that may help support heart health better than most prescriptions. These peptides don't just help enhance blood flow, they help to reduce inflammation, may help repair blood vessels, and could protect your heart at the cellular level. Here's the stack I recommend for longevity and cardiovascular protection. I'm Dr. Voss, Longevity Doctor with an MD from Cornell. You can protect your heart using tools that go way beyond pills. People think of peptides as a fitness or an anti-aging tool, but their real power may be in disease prevention, especially for the heart. This peptide stack focuses on inflammation, vascular health, and cellular repair, which are three core pillars of cardiovascular longevity. First is BPC157. This peptide is best known for its role in gut health and soft tissue healing, but emerging preclinical evidence suggests that may also support endothelial repair by promoting angiogenesis and reducing oxidative stress. Since endothelial dysfunction is an early step in atherosclerosis, BPC157's potential vascular effects could be beneficial for cardiovascular disease. Second is Thymosin Beta-4, often called Thompson Beta-500. This is another powerful healing peptide. It has been shown to improve angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels, which is critical for recovery after tissue damage. It also appears to reduce fibrosis, which is the hardening of tissues that can impair function. Third is epitalin. This is a lesser known peptide that helps to support pineal gland function and telomere repair. While it's often discussed in longevity circles, there is growing interest in its potential to reduce oxidative stress in cardiovascular tissue. Fourth is GHKCU. This copper binding peptide has demonstrated anti-inflammatory and tissue regenerative properties in preclinical studies. It also plays a role in angiogenesis, appears to potentially improve oxygen utilization at the cellular level. You don't take these peptides forever. Most of the time these are used in cycles, anywhere from 6 to 12 weeks in length, depending on the goal. They can be administered via sub-Q injection or early in the case of BPC, and some have been used intravenously. Are peptides a replacement for lifestyle? But they can accelerate repair, especially in people recovering from inflammation or metabolic issues that can put strain on the heart. The truth is that naturally occurring peptides will never be advertised the way statins are, because you can't patent your body's naturally occurring signaling molecules. But in my opinion, when used correctly and clinically monitored, they're one of the most powerful tools that we have. If you have any questions on this topic, let me know in the comments.

This video breaks down angiogenesis, the VEGF pathway, and why these processes already increase naturally through things we all do like exercise, recovery, and healing. If angiogenesis alone caused c@ncer, athletes and active people would be at constant risk. That’s not what we see in real life.

I also share my dad’s lung cancer history, his surgery, years of follow up, and the fact that he was just rescreened recently with stable results. This is not about promoting anything. It’s about adding context and nuance to a topic that gets oversimplified.

I’m not telling anyone what to take or what to do. I’m explaining the biology and sharing my family’s experience so you can better understand the conversation.

transcript: People say peptides like BPC and TB can cause cancer. My dad had lung cancer, so I actually looked into it instead of just repeating the fear online. The fear usually comes from one word, angiogenesis. That just means forming new blood vessels. Your body does this all the time. When you exercise, walk, lift weights, heal from soreness, or recover from an injury, your body increases a signal called VEGF. That's normal biology. If angiogenesis caused cancer, then athletes and active people would be at constant risk. And that's just not what we see in real life. BPC and TB interact with healing pathways your body already uses. They just amplify signals that already happen during normal recovery. And it's not one-sided. There are studies showing anti-inflammatory, anti-fibrotic, and even anti-tumor activity in certain models. Now that doesn't mean treatment or prevention. It just means the science is more nuanced than fear-based posts make it sound. This matters to me because my dad had lung cancer years ago. He had surgery, part of his lung removed, and he's been followed closely ever since. He has gone through regular imaging and screenings over the years and was just re-screened recently. And everything has been stable and clear. At no point did any doctor warn him against exercise, walking, or lifestyle habits that naturally increase VEGF. Because angiogenesis is a part of healing, not a switch that turns cancer on. I'm not telling anyone what to take, I'm explaining the science, the context, and why this conversation deserves more nuance.

transcript: New Phase 3 reddata just dropped, and I brought in a medical professional to talk about why it's significant for weight loss and joint pain. This is from Eli Lilly's Triumph 4 Phase 3 trial. Adults with knee osteoarthritis and obesity were followed for 68 weeks. The average starting weight was around 250 pounds and the average reported BMI was around 40. Now we all know BMI isn't a perfect metric and it doesn't tell us body composition or body fat distribution. But at this level it clearly represents a severely obese population with real metabolic and joint stress. Now at the highest dose of 12 mg once weekly, which is a very high dose by the way, participants lost up to 28.7% of their body weight, averaging over 70 pounds. To explain why Phase 3 data like this actually matters, here's Dr. Tuhin Chaudhry. Rahul, thank you so much for having me and thank you for the kind introduction. I'm Dr. Chaudhry, I'm a hospitalist turned wellness physician, and I wanted to discuss the Triumph 4 study with you. It was the gold standard with a randomized double-blind placebo control study. We also saw that it was a Phase 3 study, which is the last phase before it gets FDA approval. The WOMAC pain scale that they used was based on knee pain defined by knee osteoarthritis, which is joint space narrowing seen on an x-ray. And we also saw that some of their dosings were a little bit higher than what we see in the researcher world. Their starting dose was 2 mg, we typically see a lot lower starting dose. And their primary endpoint of hitting that 28.7% weight loss was at the 12 mg dosing. Some of the side effects that can occur, especially at these higher dosings, are nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and constipation. And we also saw about 10% of the population have dysthesia or paresthesia, which is that numbness and tingling that can occur on the skin. Thank you very much for having me. So yeah, this study didn't exactly tell us anything we didn't already know about RETTA, but it did confirm it at a Phase 3 scale. I'll keep breaking this down as more data comes out.
